Description: Terracotta coffin-fitting in shape of eagle-gryphon. A coffin- attachment, flat at the back, in the form of a male gryphon to left, its left foreleg extended forward and its right foreleg raised. It has an eagle’s head and a crested neck, and its wings stretch back from its chest. The tail is very short. Pressed into a one-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt. The front is covered with a worn white dressing, painted yellow and gilded. Both forepaws broken off and missing; chipped and broken.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This is a common form of early Ptolemaic terracotta coffin-fitting, from a wooden coffin, found in the cemetery north of the settlement during the Egypt Exploration Fund’s second season at Naukratis (Gardner 1888, 11, 21-27, pl.16.9; Walters 1903, C568; Watzinger 1905, 60-1; Parlasca 2001, 177, n. 17, pl. 25; Bailey 2008, 129-30, nos 3485-9). At least two mould series of Griffin (Eagle-Griffin) were found in Naukratis, though both types are difficult to distinguish, with only slight differences in wing and head shape (Museum of Fine Arts, Boston 88.805 and 88.806; City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol H2264.1; British Museum GR 1888,0601.136; 1888,0601.131; Parlasca 2001, pl. 25: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford AN1888.235; University College London Institute of Archaeology, UCL1340 and UCL1931; Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.5.1887, GR.6.1887, GR.8.1887, GR.24.1887, GR.25.1887, GR.53.1887 and GR.54.1887). Pieces, probably from the same series and said to be from Naukratis include parallels sold on the art market (Sotheby’s New York Sale Catalogues, 18 June 1991, lot 84, and 31 May 1997, lot 99, 2 examples; Parlasca 2001, pls 26 and 27.2 from the art market in Paris). All were coated with white, painted yellow and normally have traces of gilding. Fabric is consistent with Nile Delta silt fabric, and Naukratis production is most likely as coffin-fitting moulds have been found there (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford AN1896- 1908- E.4804, boukranion mould). However, gilded parallels, possibly from the same mould series, have been found in the cemetery of nearby Kom Firin (Leclant 1952, 247, fig. 30; Basta 1979, 194-5; Spencer 2008, 12), suggest these had a wider distribution and possibly other production centres. Various coffin-fitting types were used on each wooden coffin (Coffin-fittings GR 1888,0601.131-135 were from one coffin; GR1888,0601.136-9, GR1888,0601.141 and GR1926,0624.9 were from another wooden coffin).
